Windows 10, Hell, Life, and the Future (for Nikki-tan at least)

Inital Stuff

There are all sorts of security settings that are recommended to switch/setup. One thing that can be a bit tricky depending on how your laptop was setup (you got the Dell one, right?) is to have a Local User Account. This has been how Windows has normally handled users account for ages. Microsoft tries to force you to login with your Microsoft/Outlook/Hotmail account.

While much less of an issue than it used to be, you should look at making recover discs for you laptop (if you didn't pay the fee to get them). Windows 10 has a feature call Reset. This basically does a clean install of the operating system in place. I think you can have it save your user documents, settings, or something like that. I've only used it to do a full Reset to clean up a screwed up install or clean a laptop before returning it.

Basic Stuff

Searching for: how to do thingy in 'windows 10'

Searching for: how to disable thingy in 'windows 10'

Note the quotes on 'windows 10' to make sure you don't get info for other versions of Windows. Also you likely want to restrict your results to the last year. There have been a lot of major updates to Windows 10 which have notably changed things.

I'm picky about how the File Explorer looks (the side bar especially). You can remove/change/add items and their names in it to do just about anything. Most things require registry modifications. For the most common stuff, like say removing One Drive (which I personally commonly remove/disable across Windows 10), just add 'explorer' or 'file explorer' to the disable search. There a number of sites which will tell you how to do it, the better ones will have tiny registry patch files you can download and apply (by doubleclicking or right-click and telling to add to registry). This is a lot easier and less error prone than doing the registry modification by hand.

Microsoft Movie Maker

You aren't the only one pissed about this. You can still download the old Windows 7 version, it's the 2012 version from the first link in the list below. Note you have be very careful with sources on this one. A lot of people have made all sorts of malware and purchase required versions that you'll get if you search for 'Microsoft Movie Maker' or 'Movie Maker Windows 7' or such.

Open Shell

Open Shell, previouslly call Classic Shell, is the second link below. It has a number of things in it. Most important for people moving from Windows 7 to Windows 10 is you can set the Start Menu to look a few different ways (including a pretty close on to Windows 7).

This is program you'll have to install, the article wakes you through it. In my experience (I used this for a number of years), I had to reinstall it after most major Windows 10 Updates. The update would overwrite files/settings so that Windows would be using the default Start Menu again.

Once you tweak the Start Menu (removing all the stupid add tiles mainly), it's not bad. Especially if you switch to the mind set of searching for the program you want.

Windows 10 Tweaks and Links

Most of these I just googled up this morning. Though I knew the kinds of things to search for. There will be a lot of overlap. There are tons of articles on tweaking Windows 10. You can google for specific types/aspectics to tweak. Do make sure you're looking at results from the last year or so.

You Can Still Get Windows 10 for Free With a Windows 7, 8, or 8.1 Key

Upgrading your old laptop to Windows 10 might fix it's stability issues. How many applications and settings will carry over.... I dunno. If you have a big external hard drive, you can do a full backup (Clonezilla Howto) upgrade (or just try a clean install of Windows 7 or 10, the former is not for the faint of heart) and see what happens.

In closing...

Don't complain about my HTML or spelling. This wasn't a huge amount of work, but it was far from a two minute exercise.

A lot of people wish they could stick with the old versions of Windows. Windows 7 long term supported ended January 14, 2020. That means minimally no new security patches/updates. Also Windows 10 has been around long enough that most new software is written to run best/only on it. Not to mention, newer hardware requires it.

Once you turn off a lot of its annoyances and get the hang of the differences, you'll be find. We can't all be genius computer savants (I mean I can be, but you have to keep room in your head for artish stuff) but you can do this. You'd probably prefer to deal with it over the summer, but doing it now will force you to learn how to use it. Not to mention, isn't that new laptop really, really zippy even with all the Windows 10 crap running?
